description: From Middle English tribe, tribu, from Old French tribu, from Latin tribus. Doublet of tribus.

entries.meaning: (history, anthropology) An ethnic group larger than a band or clan (and which may contain clans) but smaller than a nation (and which in turn may be contained within a nation). The tribe is often the basis of ethnic identity.
examples: the Twelve Tribes of Israel, Germanic tribes, Celtic tribes

entries.meaning: (derogatory) A nation or people in an area considered culturally primitive, such as Africa, Australia or Native America.
A socially cohesive group of people within a society
(zoology) A group of apes who live and work together.
(taxonomy) A hierarchal rank between family and genus.
The collective noun for various animals.
(stock breeding) A family of animals descended from some particular female progenitor, through the female line.

verbs.description: tribe (third-person singular simple present tribes, present participle tribing, simple past and past participle tribed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To distribute into tribes or classes; to categorize.
examples: Our fowl, fish, and quadruped are well tribed.
